content: The "Incentives for Older Workers Act" includes provisions such as prohibiting benefit reduction for phased retirement, allowing delayed retirement Social Security credits, reducing benefit offset from certain earnings, establishing a National Resource Center on Aging and the Workforce, and promoting workforce investment activities for older workers. The "Incentives for Older Workers Act" prohibits benefit reduction for phased retirement under the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974. This provision ensures that defined benefit plans meet requirements for participants transitioning to phased retirement. The "Incentives for Older Workers Act" prohibits benefit reduction for phased retirement under the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974. This provision ensures that defined benefit plans meet requirements for participants transitioning to phased retirement. Specifically, the Act states that a participant's compensation should not be reduced for determining accrued benefits during phased retirement if the period begins after age 50 or after completing 30 years of service. Amendment to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 prohibits accrued benefit decrease during phased retirement for participants meeting specific criteria. Amendment to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 prohibits reduction in accrued benefits for participants in phased retirement, based on specific criteria regarding compensation and years of service. The amendments made by this section prohibit reduction in accrued benefits for participants in phased retirement, based on specific criteria regarding compensation and years of service. The changes apply to benefits payable after the date of enactment of this Act. SEC. 3 amends the Social Security Act to allow delayed retirement credits until age 72. SEC. 4 reduces Social Security benefit offsets from certain earnings. SEC. 5 establishes a National Resource Center on Aging and the Workforce. The Secretary of Labor will award a grant to establish a National Resource Center on Aging and the Workforce, which will serve as an information clearinghouse on workforce issues for older workers and identify successful practices across the United States. The National Resource Center on Aging and the Workforce will create toolkits and provide technical assistance to engage older Americans in the workforce. Information will be distributed through various channels to reach government planners, policymakers, employers, and organizations serving older adults. Authorization of Appropriations.--Funds are authorized to be appropriated each fiscal year for this section. SEC. 6. Civil Service Retirement System computation for part-time service. Section 8339(p) of title 5, United States Code, is amended to include provisions for crediting part-time service performed before or after April 7, 1986, towards annuity entitlement. The amendment to Section 8339(p) of title 5, United States Code allows for crediting part-time service towards annuity entitlement for separations from service occurring after the enactment date. SEC. 7. WORKFORCE INVESTMENT ACTIVITIES FOR OLDER WORKERS. Amendments are made to the Workforce Investment Act of 1998 regarding representation of older individuals in State and Local Boards. Older individuals' representatives from the State agency or recipients of grants under the Older Americans Act of 1965 are included in the State Boards. In the Local Boards, amendments are made to include representatives of older individuals. Amendments to the Workforce Investment Act of 1998 include representation of older individuals in State and Local Boards. Representatives from area agencies on aging or grant recipients under the Older Americans Act of 1965 are included in State Boards. Local Boards now include representatives of older individuals, with funds reserved for them from allocated funds for adults. The Workforce Investment Act of 1998 amendments ensure representation of older individuals in State and Local Boards, with 5 percent of allocated funds reserved for services for older individuals. SEC. 8. ELIGIBILITY OF OLDER WORKERS FOR THE WORK OPPORTUNITY CREDIT. The amendment to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 introduces a new category of individuals eligible for the Work Opportunity Credit - qualified older workers aged 55 or older certified by a designated local agency. The amendment to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 introduces a new category of individuals eligible for the Work Opportunity Credit - qualified older workers aged 55 or older certified by a designated local agency. The amendments specify the eligibility criteria for these individuals, including age, income limits, and types of excluded income sources. Effective date for the amendments is after the enactment of the Act for individuals starting work for the employer after that date. SEC. 9. NORMAL RETIREMENT AGE. Amendment to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 adds a special rule for determining normal retirement age for certain existing defined benefit plans. An applicable plan will not fail to meet requirements solely because it adopts a specific retirement age. The term 'applicable plan' refers to a defined benefit plan in existence at the introduction of the Incentives for Older Workers Act. The Incentives for Older Workers Act introduces a normal retirement age based on years of service specified by the plan. The plan will not be disqualified for only applying the retirement age to certain participants or employers. Additionally, an applicable plan can adopt a specific retirement age without failing to meet requirements. The Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 is amended to include a special rule for determining the normal retirement age for certain existing defined benefit plans. This rule allows applicable plans to expand the normal retirement age to additional participants or employers without disqualification. The Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 is amended to allow defined benefit plans to adopt a normal retirement age earlier than permitted under certain conditions. This rule does not affect the plan's compliance with the Act or its uniform retirement age requirement. The Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 is amended to allow defined benefit plans to adopt a normal retirement age earlier under certain conditions without affecting compliance with the Act or its uniform retirement age requirement. The amendments made by this section shall have an effective date. The amendments made by this section apply to years before, on, or after the enactment date of the Act.
